title-group.article-title: Common SNPs of AmelogeninX (AMELX) and Dental Caries Susceptibility

abstract.p: Genetic approaches have shown that several genes could modify caries susceptibility; AmelogeninX (AMELX) has been repeatedly designated. Here, we hypothesized that AMELX mutations resulting in discrete changes of enamel microstructure may be found in children with a severe caries phenotype. In parallel, possible AMELX mutations that could explain resistance to caries may be found in caries-free patients. In this study, coding exons of AMELX and exon-intron boundaries were sequenced in 399 individuals with extensive caries (250) or caries-free (149) individuals from nine French hospital groups. No mutation responsible for a direct change of amelogenin function was identified. Seven single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were found, 3 presenting a high allele frequency, and 1 being detected for the first time. Three SNPs were located in coding regions, 2 of them being non-synonymous. Both evolutionary and statistical analyses showed that none of these SNPs was associated with caries susceptibility, suggesting that AMELX is not a gene candidate in our studied population.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Analysis of accumulating data has indicated a possible hereditary predisposition to caries (Boraas et al., 1988; Conry et al., 1993; Bretz et al., 2005; Huq et al., 2005; Vieira et al., 2008), and recent genetic approaches have identified several genes that could contribute to caries susceptibility (Wright, 2010). Among them, genes encoding proteins involved in enamel formation are considered as being possibly associated with dental caries (Slayton et al., 2005; Deeley et al., 2008; Patir et al., 2008; Vieira et al., 2008; Tannure et al., 2012a). Of interest is amelogenin (AMEL), which represents almost 90% of the forming enamel matrix (Fincham et al., 1999): (i) The encoding gene, AMELX, was proposed as a possible candidate for caries susceptibility by means of genetic approaches in Turkish and Guatemalan-Mayan populations (Deeley et al., 2008; Patir et al., 2008); (ii) to date, 16 mutations have been reported as being causally associated with amelogenesis imperfecta (AI) (Lee et al., 2011); and (iii) evolutionary analyses of mammalian AMELX pointed out a region of triplet repeats considered as a ‘hotspot’ of mutations, which suggests that such changes could contribute, to some extent, by modifying enamel microstructure and thereby increasing protection against wear and microbreaks (Delgado et al., 2005; Sire et al., 2006).

Genetic susceptibility to caries manifests mainly during post-eruptive maturation of enamel, which occurs during the 2 yrs following tooth eruption (Kotsanos and Darling, 1991; Bretz et al., 2005). Consecutively, one can hypothesize that AMELX mutations resulting in discrete changes of enamel microstructure may increase individual susceptibility during this time-lap. Therefore, we investigated AMELX mutations in children with a severe caries phenotype. In parallel, in caries-free young adults, we looked for AMELX mutations that could explain resistance to caries. Analysis of our data suggests that AMELX is not a gene candidate for either caries susceptibility or caries protection in our studied population.

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: This was a multicentric transverse study. In total, 250 children with caries were enrolled consecutively during pediatrics consultation in the dental departments of nine hospital groups in France from 2007 to 2009. Children and their parents received oral and written information regarding the purpose of the study, and required consent forms were signed. The study was approved by the French Ethical Committee and registered under the number NCT00541060.

The inclusion criteria were that the child be between 2 and 17 yrs old and be diagnosed with at least 3 active dentin caries lesions with enamel cavitation, or, for permanent dentition, DMFT (Decayed, Missing, Filled, Permanent Tooth) ≥ 4, or, for mixed dentition, the addition of DMFT and dft (decayed filled deciduous tooth) ≥ 4, or, for primary dentition, dft ≥ 4.

Patients with genetic diseases (e.g., amelogenesis imperfecta, osteogenesis, and/or dentinogenesis imperfecta), or patients presenting dysplasia of enamel from medication or chemical origins, or patients with chronic systemic illness or eating disorders were not included.

Meanwhile, 149 caries-free patients were consecutively enrolled in the same dental departments. Inclusion criteria were that they be between 18 and 30 yrs old, with no caries lesions, with null DMFT, with no enamel caries (white-spot, enamel caries lesion), and with no past caries experience (null dft).

sec.title: Dental Visit
sec.p: A caries-oriented standardized questionnaire was completed by the patient or by the parents for children. For all patients, clinical examination was performed by senior dental practitioners. In addition to medical background and demographic and socio-economic data, information relating to diet and oral hygiene habits and dental background of the patient as well as of his parents and siblings was also documented. Decayed teeth (enamel dentin lesion with enamel cavitation), missing teeth, and filled teeth were noted on the dental chart of the clinical record form. The presence of caries lesions was determined by visual examination of tooth surfaces, completed if necessary by x-rays. The International Caries Detection and Assessment System (ICDAS) was used for caries diagnosis (Ekstrand et al., 1998; Pitts, 2004). DMFT and/or dft and DMFS and/or dfs were calculated from records and bitewing radiographs. A saliva sample was collected as described below.

sec.title: Saliva Collection
sec.p: Saliva samples were collected by means of a self-collection kit Oragene (DNA Genotek INC, Ottawa, ON, Canada) (Steinberg et al., 2002). Genomic DNA was isolated following the manufacturer’s protocol.

sec.title: AMELX Analysis
sec.p: All the saliva samples were centralized, and DNA analysis for AMELX was performed without information regarding the patient. The human AMELX genomic reference sequence NG_012040.1 was used to design the primers (Appendix Table 1). DNA analysis was performed for the 6 coding exons of AMELX including exon-intron boundaries (see Appendix Table 1 for the detailed process). Mutations including single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) identified in the coding sequences were compared with the mammalian AMELX evolutionary chart in the literature (Delgado et al., 2007).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Characteristics of the population were described by means and standard deviation for continuous variables, and as numbers and percentages for qualitative variables (Table 1).

td.bold: at least 1 member of the family with decay

td.italic: Once to three times a day
More than three times a day

tr.td: Consumption of sweet foods between meals (%)

td.italic: Once to three times a day
More than three times a day

fn.p: DMFT: Decayed, Missing, Filled, permanent Tooth. DMFS: Decayed, Missing, Filled permanent tooth surface. dft: decayed filled deciduous tooth. dfs: decayed filled deciduous tooth surface.

sec.p: Because AMELX is located in the X chromosome, results were stratified by gender, and analyses were refined by distinguishing homozygous from heterozygous for females. For each mutation with a minor allele frequency (MAF) > 0.05, exact allele frequency and 95% confidence intervals (CI) were estimated. For each mutation and according to gender, crude and adjusted odds ratios were estimated, with their 95% exact CI, by univariate and multivariate exact logistic regressions. Multivariate regressions were adjusted for each mutation considered individually. Three environmental factors which were the most significant predictive variables in the univariate analysis (consumption of soft drinks, parental occupational status, toothbrushing frequency) were included in the multivariate model. We also retrospectively matched 60 children with caries with a subgroup of 60 caries-free young adults with a comparable parental occupational status and performed similar multivariate analysis.
Then, for each male patient, we investigated for a potential association between SNPs and caries risk by performing a Fisher’s exact test.
All statistical analyses were done with SAS software, V9.2 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC, USA).
We retrospectively performed a power calculation (nQuery 6.01 software), according to the study sample size and by selecting a MAF of 0.2 in controls.

sec.title: Patients’ Characteristics
sec.p: In total, 399 patients were included in the study, 250 children with caries and 149 caries-free young adults as controls (Appendix Fig.). Of the 250 children, 23 were excluded mainly because their informed consent was not acceptable. Eighteen saliva samples could not be sequenced because their DNA concentration was too low. Therefore, 358 DNA samples representing 212 children with caries and 146 caries-free patients were analyzed for AMELX mutations. Table 1 gives the patients’ characteristics. Europeans were largely represented in caries-free patients (84.2%), while children with caries presented more heterogeneous geographic origins. Children with caries were well-balanced regarding gender, whereas 65.8% of female patients were caries-free. Children with caries presented extrinsic risk factors for caries and had 6.3 ± 3.4 active caries lesions (mean ± SD). Caries-free patients came from a higher socio-economic background and displayed good diet and oral hygiene habits.

sec.title: Genetic Analysis
sec.p: Sequencing of AMELX exons and their bordering intronic regions in patients revealed only the presence of SNPs (SNPs 1-7, Fig. A,B and Table 2). Screening the SNP database (dbSNP) in NCBI (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/snp/) for the AMELX reference sequence revealed that 6 of them were already registered among the 162 SNPs known to date for this gene. The only new SNP found in a single caries-free female was SNP6. Four nucleotide substitutions (SNPs 1, 2, 3, and 7) were located in non-coding regions, out of the intron splicing zones, which means that these polymorphisms could not be responsible for any modification of AMEL structure or function. The other 3 nucleotide substitutions – SNPs 4, 5, and 6 - were found in the coding exon 6.

caption.p: AMELX SNPs in the studied populations. (A) Schematic representation of AMELX (NG_012040.1). The coding exons are represented as dark blue boxes and each SNP as a red line on the gene. (B) Location and pairwise LD of the 7 SNPs identified in our study population. (For females, SNPs 5 and 6 have been merged due to their low MAF.) High pairwise LD (r2) between markers is illustrated with dark shading. The r2 values (x 100) for the marker are listed in the corresponding boxes. All genotypes are in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. (C) Alignment of the AMELX amino acid sequences of representatives of the main mammalian lineages, with particular focus on the variable region of exon 6, in which the 2 missense mutations were found. This region is characterized by the presence of large insertions and deletions in many species. At position 160 (SNP4: Val > Leu), either Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine, or Alanine is encountered in various species, or the position lacks in some species. At position 161 (SNP5: His > Gln), Histine is never changed, but this position lacks in various species, as shown here in dolphin AMELX.

fn.p: NCBI Reference sequence AMELX: NG_012040.1. g. = genomic; p. = protein. ND = Not done. MAF: Minor allele frequency in dbSNP.

sec.p: SNP4 does not change the amino acid (p.H87H). The nucleotide substitution is located far from the splicing zone and could not be responsible for any AMEL modification.

SNP5 and SNP6 are missense mutations, p.V160L and p.H161Q, respectively (Table 2). Sequence comparisons with many mammalian AMEL sequences indicate that the 2 residue substitutions are located in the variable region of AMELX encoded by the central region of exon 6. This region is considered a ‘hotspot’ of mutation, as illustrated by the presence of large insertions and deletions in many species (Fig. C). At position 160, where the SNP5 Val > Leu is identified, the residue was either substituted or deleted in various lineages during mammalian evolution. At position 161, i.e., Hist > Gln, the amino acid was deleted in some lineages. Therefore, these positions being considered variable, the 2 amino acid substitutions cannot be considered as potentially involved in a modification of AMEL function.

sec.title: SNPs and Caries Prevalence
sec.p: The frequency of SNPs 1, 3, 5, and 6 was too low in both populations to investigate for a potential effect (negative or protective) on individual caries risk (Table 2, Appendix Table 2). Despite the fact that SNPs 2 and 7 were located in intronic regions, we investigated for a potential association with caries susceptibility (Table 3). No significant association was found with the caries phenotype, but there was a trend for these mutations to be found more often in male children with caries. A total of 86 DNA samples carried SNP 4, which is located in an exonic region (Appendix Table 2); no significant association was found with the caries phenotype.

caption.p: Crude and Adjusted Odds Ratios (OR) Associated with the Caries Phenotype for SNPs with MAF > 0.05: Results of Univariate and Multivariate Logistic Regression Analyses

fn.p: For each SNP with MAF > 0.05, OR are adjusted for consumption of soft drinks, toothbrushing frequency, and parental occupational status. **95% exact Confidence Intervals.

sec.p: Whatever the mutations, when the analyses were adjusted for environmental factors, the odds ratios (OR) associated with caries phenotype were still not statistically significant, and most of them were close to 1 (Table 3). By contrast, the environmental factors had statistically significant OR ranging from 5 to 15 (Appendix Table 3).

For each male patient, we then investigated for a potential association of SNPs resulting in a specific caries risk, because haplotypes are directly available for this gender. This analysis did not reveal a specific association with the present sample and the DNA region sequenced.

Finally, we retrospectively performed a power calculation and found that, for the whole population (212 cases/146 controls), there was a 96% power to detect an OR ≥ 2.5 for having a caries phenotype. When stratified by gender, the power was 78% for females (108 cases/96 controls) and 56% for males (104 cases/50 controls). For patients matched for parental occupational status, the power value was 56% (OR ≥ 2.5; 60 cases/60 controls).

sec.title: Specific AMELX SNPs May Not Be Associated with Dental Caries Susceptibility
sec.p: This study shows that the sequencing of all the coding regions of AMELX in a large cohort of children with severe caries phenotype did not reveal a mutation associated with increased caries susceptibility. This finding differs from previous reports produced by several studies. Indeed, both genetic studies based on genotyping SNP markers (Deeley et al., 2008; Patir et al., 2008) and evolutionary analyses of mammalian AMELX (Delgado et al., 2005; Sire et al., 2006) had pointed to AMELX as a candidate to carry mutations increasing individual susceptibility to caries. It is noteworthy that our population with caries presented other cariogenic risk factors, related to their environment, that reflect the population seeking dental care in public hospitals. However, when we retrospectively matched 60 children with caries with a subgroup of 60 caries-free young adults with the same socio-economic status, analysis of our data indicated no association between SNPs and phenotype (Appendix Table 4).

In this study, despite the fact that 7 AMELX SNPs were found, 3 of them with a high frequency, none could be associated with patients’ susceptibility to caries. The multivariate analysis did not provide a significant association between AMELX SNPs and caries susceptibility. Noteworthy, our population with caries was heterogeneous regarding geographic origins. Interestingly, previous studies indicating AMELX as a candidate gene for caries susceptibility were conducted by means of genetic approaches on a homogeneous population (Deeley et al., 2008; Patir et al., 2008). Therefore, it is possible that, in populations with a genetically narrow background, a sporadic genetic mutation might have appeared, increasing susceptibility to caries. However, sequencing AMELX in 70 children of the Turkish population studied by Patir and co-workers does not support this gene as a candidate for caries susceptibility (Shimizu et al., 2012). Furthermore, recent genome-wide association studies carried out on larger and more heterogeneous populations (Vieira et al., 2008; Shaffer et al., 2011, 2013) have not targeted AMELX, a finding which is consistent with the results of our study.

Six SNPs out of the 7 found in our study were already reported in the NCBI database (dbSNP), and the only one being identified for the first time was SNP6 (Table 2). The MAF of the 6 SNPs in our population is rather similar to that reported in dbSNP for the global human population (the 1000 Genomes Project, Phase 1, http://www.1000genomes.org/). Interestingly, SNP5 is known to have a low MAF in human populations (< 0.0005), except in African Americans (0.014). Here, this SNP was identified in two patients with caries, one originating from the French Caribbean and the other from North Africa. This suggests that further investigations more targeted on these populations may find a potential association of this variant with caries susceptibility.

Statistical analyses indicated that, at least for SNPs 2 and 7, the genetic polymorphism identified in intronic regions and located far from the splice sites may not be associated with individual caries susceptibility. Furthermore, when tested in multivariate models, the SNPs identified in our study population were not associated with the caries phenotype. To date, our study is the largest one to sequence AMELX and study, with sufficient power, the relationship between mutations of this gene and susceptibility to caries. In addition, our study is the first to our knowledge stratified analyses by gender because AMELX is located on the X chromosome.

However, the possibility that other enamel-related genes may present mutations increasing individual caries susceptibility must not be rejected (Slayton et al., 2005; Vieira et al., 2008; Wright, 2010). For example, a recent study has indicated that MMP-20 may be a potential candidate for caries susceptibility (Tannure et al., 2012b). This study has shown differences for Europeans in genotype distribution in caries-free children vs. children with caries.

sec.title: Specific AMELX SNPs Are Not Associated with Dental Caries Protection
sec.p: We took the opportunity of the large number of patients with no past caries experience to test the hypothesis that AMELX mutations would increase a patient’s resistance to caries. This hypothesis was not supported by our analysis of the genetic polymorphisms identified in the present study: AMELX SNPs are not associated with caries protection. In a previous study, sequencing the variable AMELX region in a heterogeneous human population did not reveal genetic polymorphism (Richard et al., 2007). The lack of substitutions was related to the high constraints acting on this AMELX region in relation to its location on the X chromosome. However, in the present study, we identified 2 SNPs (SNPs 5 and 6) in the coding variable AMELX region, which supports that this less-constrained region allows mutations to occur.

In conclusion, this study suggests that the SNPs identified in AMELX are not significantly associated with caries susceptibility and that the few AMELX sequence variations may not be predictors of caries susceptibility in the studied population.

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Marilyne Delattre and Laurence Lecomte (URC Paris Centre, AP-HP, France) for their help in conducting this study. The authors thank Pr Françoise Clerget (Inserm U 781, Hopital Necker, Paris, France) for her help with the analysis of genetic data.

fn.p: This study was supported by AP-HP, CRC 06063 CARIOGENE.
The authors declare no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
